Graphical abstract CaO doped iron–alumina-supported nickel–iron alloy catalysts were tested in a fixed-bed reactor for steam reforming of toluene as a biomass tar model compound at a relatively low steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of 2. The influence of doping CaO to iron–alumina support was also explored for the steam reforming reaction. Ni supported on a CaO(1.5)–Fe2O3–Al2O3 support (Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al) gave superior catalytic performance in terms of activity and stability over other catalysts. Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al gave a toluene conversion of more than 80% for a period of 22h testing at a S/C ratio of 2. XRD analysis showed that the Ni–Fe alloys formed were stable throughout the reforming reaction. It was observed from XPS results that the surface of the reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst was enriched with Fe species compared to other catalysts. These enriched surface Fe species play the role of co-catalysts by increasing the coverage of oxygen species during the reforming reaction to enhance the reaction of toluene and to suppress coke formation. The temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with water reveals that the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst can activate water molecule at relatively lower temperature over other CaO doped catalysts. TGA analysis on spent catalysts reveals that all CaO-containing catalysts generally result in lower carbon formation rates as compared to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. Keywords Hydrogen production Nickel–iron alloy Biomass Toluene steam reforming CaO promoted iron–alumina 1 Introduction Catalytic steam reforming of biomass tar to produce H2-rich synthesis gas is increasingly attractive because of the rising interest in utilizing biomass derived from forest, agricultural, and municipal solid waste materials as a renewable energy source [1–5]. However, one of the most critical problems in utilization of biomass via gasification and/or pyrolysis at low temperature (500–650°C) is the formation of tars, an undesirable reaction that is an impediment to the commercialization of the biomass utilization process. In addition, these tars are largely aromatic hydrocarbons, such as benzene, toluene, and naphthalene, which harness large amounts of energy, thereby lowering the energy content of the product gas. These tars also cause operational problems when cooled and condensed in heat exchangers, lowering heat transfer efficiencies, plugging pipes, and so on. Therefore, efficient conversion of biomass tars is crucial in the biomass gasification and/or pyrolysis processes. Among many processes [6,7], catalytic steam reforming of biomass tar is a considerably attractive approach for tar removal during biomass gasification and/or pyrolysis processes since it produces syngas, which is a high-value gas product [8–10]. Hence, it is greatly essential to develop highly effective catalysts that are capable of converting the biomass tar to synthesis gas. Among the effective supported metal (such as Ni, Co, Rh, Pt, Pd, etc.) catalysts [11–13], Ni-based catalysts have been widely investigated for the steam reforming of biomass tar because of its low cost, abundance and high activity [14–16]. However, the major drawback for Ni catalysts is their rapid deactivation due to the coke deposition [17]. In the process of developing highly effective Ni-based catalysts, several approaches reported include modification of Ni with other metal oxides [18–20], alloying with other transition metals [21–25], identification of suitable support [26,27] and modification of support with other metal oxides [18,28]. Among them, alloying of Ni with other metals is one of the promising approaches in recent times to improve the catalytic performance in terms of activity, stability and coke resistance. One such suitable modifier is Fe [22–24,29–31]. Ni–Fe bimetallic catalysts have been reported to be effective for the catalytic reforming of methane, iso-octane, biomass tar, and tar model compounds [29–34]. Our previous studies [22,23] have also shown that improved performance in steam reforming activity for Ni–Fe catalysts is due to the presence of an intimate interaction between Fe and Ni, which results in the formation of a Ni–Fe alloy. Tomishige et al. [24] also obtained a similar conclusion for Ni–Fe/Al2O3 catalyst in cellulose gasification. In addition, Tomishige et al. [29,31] has also recently reported that the presence of uniform Ni–Fe alloy particles in Ni–Fe/Mg/Al catalysts enables a high catalytic performance in the steam reforming of toluene and phenol. As has been reported [22–24], Fe plays the role of a co-catalyst. Since Fe has a higher oxygen affinity than Ni, the addition of Fe to Ni catalysts can increase the coverage of oxygen atoms during the steam reforming reactions. This increment in oxygen coverage is vital in enhancing the performance of Ni–Fe alloy species in steam reforming of tar. Additionally, in order to improve the catalytic performance further, modification of catalyst support has also been suggested in literature. Catalysts with basic properties tend to decrease the rate of coke formation in many reforming reactions, such as steam reforming of toluene [18,30], CO2 reforming of methane [35–37], steam reforming of methane [37], steam reforming of ethanol [38,39], which in turn leads to reduced catalyst deactivation over time and helps to increase the stability of the catalyst. Furthermore, calcium oxide (CaO) is widely known to be a CO2 sorbent, assisting the production of hydrogen-rich gas [40,41] in biomass gasification for hydrogen production. This option has recently gained tremendous attention due to the low cost and abundance of CaO [42,43]. CaO can play the vital roles of not only CO2 sorbent, but also tar reforming catalyst [43]. Removing CO2 from the gasification reaction as soon as it is formed alters the equilibrium composition of the produced gas and promotes the production of gas rich in hydrogen [42]. In steam reforming of ethanol, the addition of CaO to Ni catalyst could prevent the formation of crystalline carbon which is more difficult to be removed, resulting in higher catalyst stability. Moreover, it was reported that Ca addition promoted water adsorption and provided abundance of adsorbed OH groups on Ni catalyst which could facilitate the CC break, resulting in higher ethanol conversion [38,39]. It has been reported [44–48] that the surface properties of Ni/Al2O3 systems could be improved by introduction of alkaline earth metal oxides (MgO and CaO) due to the increase of steam-carbon reaction and the neutralization of the acidity of the support to suppress cracking and polymerization reactions. In biomass gasification, it was also reported that basic nature of a catalyst is favorable for tar decomposition catalysts since higher catalyst basicity can enhance the catalyst activity [49]. Recently, we have reported [22] Ni–Fe alloy supported over Fe2O3–Al2O3 catalysts for steam reforming of toluene (SRT) at 650°C. In that study, we have observed that Ni/Fe2O3–Al2O3 catalyst calcined at 900°C (Ni/Fe–Al) is able to activate water molecule more effectively at lower temperatures than other catalysts calcined at lower temperatures. Building on the strength of this catalyst, we explored Ni/Fe–Al catalyst system further in this study at a considerably low steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of 2. In order to improve the catalytic performance further, we doped Ni/Fe–Al catalysts system with various amounts of Ca species to obtain Ni–Fe alloy supported over CaO–Fe2O3–Al2O3 system. The thus-obtained catalysts were investigated for their catalytic performance for steam reforming of toluene (SRT) as a biomass tar model compound at a reaction temperature of 500–800°C and at S/C ratio of 2. Steam reforming of toluene proceeds according to the reactions as shown below, followed by water gas shift reaction. (1) C7H8 +7H2O→7CO+11H2 (S/C=1) (2) C7H8 +14H2O→7CO2 +18H2 (S/C=2) (3) CO+H2O→CO2 +H2 Other reactions such as dry reforming, hydrodealkylation, carbon formation by toluene decomposition and cracking are also included in this process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CaO–Fe2O3–Al2O3 mixed oxides (nominal Ca:Fe:Al molar ratios of 0:1:2, 0.5:1:2, 1:1:2, 1.5:1:2 and 2:1:2) were prepared using a co-precipitation method. In a typical preparation method, nearly saturated solutions of nitrates (ferric nitrate, calcium nitrate and aluminum nitrate) were homogeneously mixed in the required molar ratios. The pH value of the solution was slowly adjusted to ∼10 with 2M aqueous ammonia solution, and the solution was then stirred continuously for another 1h to complete the precipitation process. The precipitated solution was dried in an oven at 100°C for 24h and then calcined at 900°C for 4h in an air atmosphere. The as-prepared catalyst supports were labeled as Ca(x)–Fe–Al, where x represents the molar composition of Ca species. The 10wt.% Ni supported catalysts were prepared by a simple wetness impregnation method wherein an aqueous solution containing the required amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was mixed with the requisite amount of support material to yield the respective Ni weight percent needed. The mixtures were then dried under constant stirring at 80°C and further dried at 100°C for another 24h before they were calcined in air at 700°C for 4h. The thus-prepared catalysts were labeled as Ni/Ca(x)–Fe–Al, where x represents the nominal molar composition of Ca species in CaO–Fe2O3–Al2O3 support. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface areas of the freshly calcined catalysts and their supports were measured by N2 physical adsorption at −196°C in an ASAP 2020 instrument. The specific surface area was calculated by applying the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The actual compositions of all the calcined catalysts were measured using Scanning Electron Microscope coupled to an Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (SEM-EDX, Jeol, JSM-6701F). The samples were degassed under vacuum condition to remove impurities. Platinum coating (about 10nm thickness) was carried out at 20mA for 40s. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of each catalyst was measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The catalyst was placed on an aluminum slide and scanned from 2θ of 20° to 80° at a ramp rate of 2°/min. The beam voltage and current used were 40kV and 30mA, respectively. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements for fresh catalysts were performed on a Quantachrome ChemBET-3000 instrument. Prior to the TPR measurement, 0.04g of catalyst was outgassed in He for 1h at 300°C to remove any moisture and then cooled to room temperature. Then 5% H2/N2 gas was introduced to the catalyst while the furnace temperature was increased at a heating rate of 10°C/min to 1000°C. The CO chemisorption was done in the Quantachrome ChemBET-3000 instrument. Prior to the CO pulse chemisorption measurement, the sample (W =50mg) was reduced at 700°C for 1h under H2 gas before it was cooled to 0°C in a helium flow of 80mL/min. The CO chemisorption was measured at 0°C by introducing pulses of CO using 5% CO/He with a loop volume of 250μL. The pulses were continued until no further uptake of CO was measured. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 profiles were analyzed using mass spectroscopy (Thermostat GSD300). 100mg of catalyst sample was used in each analysis. Prior to the adsorption of CO2, the sample was reduced at 700°C for 1h under H2 gas environment. After that the samples were cooled to 50°C where CO2 adsorption was carried out for 30min. Then the samples were purged in He gas for 30min. Desorption of CO2 took place while heating the sample from room temperature of 30–1000°C with a ramp rate of 10°C/min. For temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) experiments with water, about 50mg of catalyst sample was loaded in an isothermal zone of the reactor. Prior to the TPSR measurement, the catalyst was reduced in H2 gas at 700°C for 1h. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, the H2 gas was switched to 80mL/min of He gas saturated with water at room temperature, which was then increased to 900°C at a rate of 10°C/min. The reactor effluent gas was analyzed by mass spectroscopy (Thermostat GSD300). The catalyst surface analysis was performed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) from a KRATOS AXIS Hsi 165 equipped with Mg-Kα source (1253.6eV). Prior to the analysis, the catalyst was reduced at 700°C under H2 for 1h which is the same as the reduction condition during reaction. The sample was then mounted on the standard sample stub using double-sided adhesive tapes. All binding energies were referenced to C 1s hydrocarbon peak at 284.6eV. The total amount and nature of deposited carbon on the spent catalysts were measured using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) on a Shimadzu DTG-60 thermogravimetric analyzer, respectively. Around 5mg of spent catalyst was used in each DTA/TGA experiment and heated in air to 1000°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with an inner diameter of 4mm and a length of 400mm as reported previously [18,23]. The catalyst in each test was sandwiched between quartz wool placed in the middle of the reactor. The operating conditions were as follows: catalysts amount=0.03 or 0.05g; toluene amount=188μmol (diluted by He gas); S/C ratio=2; reaction temperature=550–800°C. Prior to the catalytic reaction, the catalyst was reduced in H2 (30mL/min) at 700°C for 1h and then purged in helium (120mL/min) while the temperature ramped to the desired reaction temperature. Water and toluene were vaporized at 300°C in a preheater and mixed with He (120mL/min) gas before entering the main reactor in the vapor state. Next, the reaction products were then passed through a cold trap at a temperature of 5°C to condense the unreacted toluene and water from the gasification reaction. The non-condensable gas product was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (HP 6890) equipped with a Carboxen column and a thermal conductivity detector. The chromatogram showed peak areas for all of the reacted gases, which were then converted to volume percent using a calibration curve. The total flow rate of the product gases was measured using a bubble flow meter. The conversion of toluene was expressed in terms of carbon conversion, which was calculated using the following formula: (4) X Toluene (%)=(n CO + n CO2)*100/(7* n r in) where n j is the molar flow rate of gas j. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst activity and stability study 3.1.1 Steam reforming of toluene over Ni/Ca-Fe-Al catalysts The catalytic performance for steam reforming of toluene as a biomass tar model compound was carried out in a continuous fixed-bed reactor over 10wt.% Ni supported on Fe2O3–Al2O3 and CaO doped Fe2O3–Al2O3 supports. The reaction was performed at 650°C with relatively low S/C ratio of 2. Table 1 presents the product gas distributions, H2/CO molar ratios, and catalytic performances for Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts after 4h reaction time. In this SRT reaction, the main product stream consists of H2, CO, CO2, and trace amounts of CH4 (<1%). According to Table 1, toluene conversion value of 78.87% obtained over Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst is highest among all other catalysts. It was also observed that the H2, CO, and CO2 yields increased correspondingly with increasing toluene conversion. In comparison, all CaO-doped Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts produced significantly higher H2/CO values between 2.46 and 3.75 compared with Ni/Fe–Al catalyst which has a H2/CO value of 1.81. It is also observed that the H2/CO values were increased with increasing CaO content in the catalysts to an optimum catalyst composition of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. This increase in the H2/CO value for all the CaO contained catalysts over Ni/Fe–Al is because these catalysts have higher amounts of available surface Fe species (to be shown later from XPS analysis) and the ability to activate steam at relatively lower temperatures (to be shown in TPSR with water analysis), and these attributes apparently promotes the water–gas shift (WGS) reaction. These H2/CO values are also much higher than the H2/CO ratio of 1.6 produced from the stoichiometric condition of steam reforming of toluene (Eq. (1)). The higher syngas ratio obtained indicates the presence of side reactions to produce more H2 and/or consume more CO. According to reports, Eqs. (1) and (2) represents the ideal SRT reactions at S/C ratios of 1 and 2, respectively. Eq. (3) represents the WGS reaction to produce CO2 and more H2. The CO2 produced by Eqs. (2) and (3) may react with toluene according to dry reforming of toluene. A comparison of the obtained results (Table 1) and the above possible reactions clearly shows that at a S/C ratio of 2, the toluene reforming reaction did not proceed according to Eq. (2). Instead, it is more appropriate to postulate that it proceeds according to SRT with an S/C ratio of 1 (Eq. (1)) followed by the WGS reaction (Eq. (3)). This suggests that the SRT performance of any catalyst is highly dependent on their ability in promoting WGS reaction. Furthermore, the time-dependent catalytic performances of Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts for 4h of reaction time are depicted in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1 shows that the overall catalytic performance of CaO doped Ni/Fe–Al catalysts showed better performance over Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. This also shows that the addition of CaO to Ni/Fe–Al catalysts enhanced the catalytic performances of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts up to an optimum composition of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. It can also be observed from Fig. 1(a) that all the catalysts showed a decreasing trend of catalytic performance with increasing time on stream. This decrease is higher for Ni/Fe–Al catalyst than CaO-doped catalysts. The deterioration in catalytic performance with time is primarily due to the deposition of carbon species over the active metal centers present in the catalysts during the SRT process at 650°C. This deposited carbon can encapsulate the active metal species, resulting in a decrease in the amount of catalytically active species [17]. The nature and amount of carbon species deposited over spent catalysts were characterized using DT/TG analyses, and the results will be discussed in later parts of this article. In addition, structural changes within the Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts during the SRT process can also play an important role in their catalytic performance with time on stream. These structural changes were identified by characterizing reduced and spent Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts, and the obtained results will also be discussed later in this article. According to Fig. 1, the overall catalytic performances are in the increasing order of Ni/Fe–Al<Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al<Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al<Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al<Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts. On the other hand, the H2 selectivity during SRT reaction in terms of H2/CO values with time on steam for Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts is depicted in Fig. 1(b), which shows that all CaO contained Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts produced higher H2/CO values compared to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. The H2/CO values for the catalysts (Fig. 1(b)) decrease in the order of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al>Ni/Fe–Al. This suggests that Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst showed superior SRT catalytic performance in terms of conversion, stability, and H2/CO value for ca. 4h reaction time compared with the other catalysts. 3.1.2 Influence of reaction temperature In order to study the influence of reaction temperature on products, Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al was selected and detailed product distribution as well as toluene conversion are shown in Fig. 2 . This temperature programmed steam reforming of toluene reaction was performed with reaction temperatures ranging from 550 to 800°C, and was held for 1h at every 50°C increment over Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. As the reaction temperature was increased from 550 to 700°C, catalytic conversions showed a sharp increment, indicating the endothermic nature of steam reforming reaction. This increment in conversion is not as sharp when the reaction temperature was raised from 700 to 750°C. Above 750°C, toluene conversion reached almost 100% and was converted to CO, CO2, CH4 and H2 gases. CH4 gas was observed above 650°C and the selectivity towards CH4 gas was almost <2% at all reaction temperatures. On the other hand, selectivity for CO gas was increased, while selectivity for CO2 gas decreased as the reaction temperature was increased from 550 to 700°C. This phenomenon can be attributed to the increase in the dominance of endothermic reactions (1) and (3) as temperature was increased. Furthermore, above 700°C, decrease in H2 gas selectivity associated with a decrease in CO2 and an increase in CO selectivity was observed. The evolution of these results is due to the important participation of the reverse water gas shift reaction, which is thermodynamically favorable at high temperatures. This result suggests that the reaction temperature 650°C is sufficient to attain reasonably high toluene conversion with high selectivity towards H2 gas production. 3.1.3 Catalyst stability study The catalytic performance in terms of stability for longer reaction times were also carried out over Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. The following severe experimental conditions were imposed to examine the stability for the SRT reaction: toluene=188μmolmin−1 (diluted by He gas); S/C ratio=2; reaction temperature=650°C; W =50mg. Fig. 3 displays the conversion of toluene and the product distributions as functions of reaction time (h). It is observed that the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst was able to give a conversion of above 90% in the initial runtime of 3h, then decreased slightly before maintaining the toluene conversion of around 80% for a period of 22h reaction time. It is noteworthy to mention here that the carbon formation rate for this run is 13mg/g–cath and the Ni crystallite size was found to have decreased from 22.3nm to 11.5nm after catalyzing the SRT reaction for 22h. The slower decrease in catalytic performance with time at the initial reaction period is primarily due to the deposition of carbon species over the catalysts as well as the structural changes within the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts during the SRT process which can also play an important role in the catalytic performance of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts with time on stream. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Surface area and SEM-EDX analyses Table 2 shows the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas and actual elemental compositions of Ni supported Fe–Al and Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. The surface area results in Table 2 show that all CaO-doped catalysts have higher surface areas than Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. In general, in all the species present in the Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts, Al2O3 is known to be the major surface area contributor. It is also observed that the surface area of Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al catalyst has an area of 38m2/g in contrast to the un-doped Ni/Fe–Al catalyst which has an area of 14.2m2/g. This higher surface area for Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al catalysts over Ni/Fe–Al catalyst is possibly due to the formation of calcium–alumina spinel (Ca–Al–O) composite molecules during the preparation of catalyst. Even though we did not find any evidence to show the formation of Ca–Al–O composites in this study, it is known from literature reports that heat treatment at 900°C on the mixture of Ca and Al precursors can form Ca–Al–O composite materials [45]. On the other hand, excess CaO doping to Ni/Fe–Al catalysts can cause decrease in the surface area as a result of penetration of excess CaO species into the pores of catalyst support during preparation of the support material. 3.2.2 XRD analysis of reduced and spent catalysts Fig. 4(a) shows the XRD patterns of freshly reduced Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts for 2θ =36–50°. All of the patterns in Fig. 4(a) show a diffraction peak corresponding to the Ni metal phase that is centered at around 2θ =44.6° (JCPDS # 04-0850). However, a gradual shift to smaller angle was observed for the patterns of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts with increasing CaO content. This shift is more obvious for the pattern of Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalyst. According to previous report [50], the shift is interpreted to result from the creation of defect sites in the metallic Ni phase by Fe species, thus resulting in the formation of a Ni-rich Ni–Fe alloy with a face-centered-cubic (fcc) structure. It is also observed that the intensity of this metallic peak is significantly reduced in CaO-doped Ni/Fe–Al catalysts, especially for Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalyst. This is because of a decrease in the bulk content of Ni/Fe–Al catalysts upon addition of CaO species. The average particle size of metallic Ni was determined by broadening of the (111) line of nickel at around 44.6° [51]. According to the Ni particle sizes presented in Table 3 , the average Ni particle sizes of all Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts were found to be lower than Ni/Fe–Al catalyst except for Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalyst. This lower Ni crystallite size of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al over Ni/Fe–Al is attributed either to higher surface area of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al or due to increase in interaction between Fe and Ni species by doping of CaO to Ni/Fe–Al catalysts. This observation is further supported from XPS analysis of reduced catalysts which will be discussed in the later parts of this manuscript. In addition to the peaks belonging to metallic Ni, all the profiles show a peak at around 2θ =43.5°, which is assigned to a Fe-rich Ni–Fe alloy with fcc structure [52]. Furthermore, the broadness of this Ni–Fe alloy peak suggests that the Fe and Ni compositions are not uniform in the alloy phase that was formed. Together with the TPR results (which will be presented later in Fig. 5 ), the results reveal that reduced Fe species can interact with reduced Ni species to form Ni–Fe bimetallic compounds. On the other hand, the XRD pattern of Ni/Fe–Al catalyst in Fig. 4(a) has a peak at around 2θ =43.1° that is assigned to the Al2O3-rich Fe2O3 corundum phase [53]. This phase is relatively inert, thereby inferring that it is thermally stable and is hard to reduce. This peak is not observed in CaO-doped Ni/Fe–Al catalysts, suggests the role of CaO in reducing the interaction of Fe with Al species. The characteristic XRD peaks corresponding to calcium oxide (CaO) and Ca–Al–O are not observed in Fig. 4(a). The absence of CaO and Ca–Al–O peaks, which should be formed after decomposition of respective nitrate precursors during calcination at 900°C for 4h, indicates that CaO and Ca–Al–O are amorphous or well mixed with other support phases. It is noteworthy to mention here that formation of various calcium aluminates (Ca–Al X ) and mayenite-like structures were reported by others [46,54,55] during the synthesis of Ca–Al materials. However, in Fig. 4(a) we did not find any evidence to confirm the presence of those phases. The presence of Ni–Fe bimetallic compounds on the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst was also confirmed after a life test for 4h and 22h, as shown in Fig. 4(b). It can be observed from Fig. 4(b) that the peak intensities of both spent catalysts appeared to be considerably lower than XRD pattern of reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. This is possibly due to the deposition of carbon species over the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst during the SRT process. From the XRD patterns of spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts shown in Fig. 4(b), the peak assigned to the metallic Ni phase was weaker and shifted to lower angles. This shifted peak can be assigned to the formation of Ni-rich Ni–Fe alloy phase (at 2θ =44.3°) [50]. The peak assigned to the Fe-rich Ni–Fe alloy phase has also become weaker but remains present in spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst even after the catalyst was tested for 22h. The average particle sizes of this Ni-rich Ni–Fe alloy phase were determined at around 2θ =44.3° and were observed to be lower (ca. 18.4 and 11.5nm for 4 and 22h spent catalysts, respectively) than the metallic Ni crystallite size of reduced catalyst (21.4nm). This phenomenon of lower particle size for the spent catalysts is probably due to the formation of a reasonably low crystalline Ni-rich Ni–Fe alloy phase during the SRT process at a reaction temperature of 650°C. Finally, it can be concluded from XRD analysis of reduced and spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst that the presence of intimate interactions between Ni and Fe species is stable throughout the SRT reaction at 650°C for 22h reaction time for Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. 3.2.3 H2-temperature programmed reduction analysis H2-TPR experiments were carried to understand the reducibility of Ni and Fe species present in Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the TPR profiles of Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts calcined at 700°C/4h. The TPR profile of Ni/Fe–Al catalyst has three reduction centers. Firstly, a low-temperature reduction peak ranging from 350 to 550°C and centered at 470°C can be attributed to the reduction of Fe species (Fe2O3 to Fe3O4) [53]. According to the literature [56], un-interacted Ni species are also reduced in this reduction temperature range. However, because of the presence of alumina in the γ-phase, these Ni species are expected to have strong interactions with support elements under the present catalyst preparation conditions. This suggests that the low-temperature reduction peak is mainly due to the reduction of Fe species. Secondly, a moderate-temperature reduction peak ranging from 550 to 800°C can be assigned to the conversion (to Ni0) of NiO species that have interacted with Fe species. According to previous report [57], in Ni–Fe bimetallic catalysts, the Ni reduction center shifts to higher temperature with an increase in the interaction with Fe species in the catalyst. Lastly, the high-temperature reduction peak starting from 750 to 1000°C can be attributed to the reduction of Ni species in NiAl2O4 spinel [57]. These three reduction centers are also present in the TPR profiles of all Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. However, the second reduction center is shifted slightly to higher temperature region especially for Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al and Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts. This slight shift to higher temperature region is reported to be because of an increase in Ni–Fe interactions [22]. Finally, the high temperature reduction peak between 700 and 1000°C can be attributed to the reduction of Ni species in NiAl2O4 spinel. The intensity of this high temperature reduction peak is increased with increasing amount of CaO species in the catalyst except for Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts. This increase in the intensity is because presence of CaO species can decrease interaction of Al with Fe species during the synthesis of support material, which ultimately results in the increase in the amount of Al species available to interact with Ni species in the catalyst to form NiAl2O4 spinel. The total H2 consumption for Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts during TPR process up to 1000°C are presented in Table 3. It is observed from Table 3 that increasing CaO content in Ni/Fe–Al catalyst also increases H2 consumption value to an optimum composition of Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al catalyst. Furthermore, prior to use in SRT reaction, the catalyst were pretreated with H2 gas at 700°C/1h. During this process, Fe species is firstly reduced prior to interacting with the reduced Ni species to form bimetallic Ni–Fe alloy species. Finally, TPR analysis suggests that the presence of CaO species in the catalyst support decrease the interaction of Fe with Al species, thus enhancing the interaction of Ni species with Fe and Al species separately. TPR analysis also suggests that the interactions of Ni species with Fe and Al species are higher for Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst than other CaO-doped catalysts. This in turn helps to establish intimate interaction between Ni and Fe species, an essential attribute that the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst possess, leading to better SRT performance for Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst over other catalysts. 3.2.4 Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 The basic strength of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al and Ni/Fe–Al catalysts was measured using CO2-TPD up to 900°C and the results are presented in Fig. 6 . All the profiles for Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts in Fig. 6 shows two-stage CO2 desorption peaks, with the first peak being a low temperature intense CO2 desorption peak ranging from 100 to 350°C. These peaks can be assigned to low-strength basic sites, such as bicarbonates that result from the interactions between CO2 and weak basic surface hydroxyl groups [39]. Secondly, broad CO2 desorption peak was observed at a moderate temperature range of 400–600°C. This latter peak is probably due to high-strength basic sites such as unidentate carbonates [58]. On the other hand, the CO2 desorption profile for Ni/Fe–Al catalyst has a significant low temperature desorption peak ranging from 100 to 350°C, while the moderate temperature desorption peak in the range of 400–600°C, is almost negligible. In Fig. 6, the low temperature CO2 desorption peak for Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al catalyst was centered at around 140°C, whereas the CO2 desorption peaks for all other Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts are centered at around 125°C. Furthermore, the basic strength based on this CO2 desorption temperature is in the decreasing order of Ni/Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al∼Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts. Unlike the low temperature CO2 desorption peak, the moderate temperature desorption peak exist at similar temperature range for all the Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. According to literature [39,58], this moderate temperature CO2 desorption peak is generally observed because of the presence of over-saturated CaO species. This CaO species adsorbs CO2 much stronger than those Ca ions dispersed in the Al2O3 matrix. This suggests that even at CaO molar ratio of 0.5 (the lowest CaO content catalyst studied in this work) in Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al catalyst, there is over-saturation of Ca species in the catalysts. This might be one of the reasons for the similar CO2 desorption behaviors at moderate temperature region for all the Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. In order to compare the actual basicity of all the catalysts, the amount of CO2 desorbed based on the results shown in Fig. 6 has been determined and the obtained results are normalized by dividing with the surface area values of that catalyst sample as given in Table 2. Thus, the obtained rationalized basicity values are 3.6, 16.4, 16.7, 16.9 and 24.7μmol/m2 for Ni/Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al and Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts, respectively. It is observed from the results that the basicity of Ni/Fe–Al catalysts has been tremendously increased with the doping of CaO species. The basicity is observed to increase with increasing CaO content in the catalysts. This increase is observed to be high for Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalyst, which has higher amount of CaO content than all other catalysts and also has lower surface area over other CaO doped catalysts. Thus this suggests, an optimum basicity is sufficient enough to get better SRT rates whereby higher basicity leads to lowering of SRT activity as was observed over (2.0)CaO contained Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalyst. The basicity of these catalysts enables them to neutralize the acidity of the supports, thereby suppressing cracking and polymerization reactions. This suppression in turn leads to enhanced steam-coke reaction, which ultimately decreases the carbon deposition over active metal surface during SRT reaction. 3.2.5 Temperature programmed surface reaction with water Since SRT process in this present work was performed at relatively low S/C ratio of 2, the splitting of water by Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts during SRT process is believed to be crucial in determining the catalytic performances of various Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. Therefore, in order to understand the nature of active centers and their capability to activate water molecules, TPSR of water over reduced Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts was performed. Fig. 7 shows the H2 evolution as a function of temperature during TPSR with water over the Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. In the TPSR with water experiments, only H2 evolved, and this can be explained according to Eqs. (5) and (6): (5) M*+H2O→H2 +M*O (6) M*O+S→M*+S−O where M* is an active metal center (Ni0 or Ni–Fe alloy) and S is an oxygen-vacant center in the support. Generally, in the Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts, two active centers (metallic Ni, Ni–Fe alloy species) may exist to activate water molecules in order to generate H2 gas. According to previous report [22], Ni/Fe–Al catalyst has two H2 evolution peaks: (1) a low temperature peak centered at around 370°C that is due to active sites found on metallic Ni, and (2) the high temperature peak centered at around 600°C that is possibly from Ni–Fe alloy active centers. Here in Fig. 7, a broad H2 evolution peak is observed starting from 400 to 800°C with T max ranging 600–630°C for all Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. It is also observed that the T max for H2 evolution peak was shifted to lower temperatures with increasing CaO content. Thus, the decreasing order of T max is in the following order: Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al>Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al∼Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts. Since most of the H2 evolution is in the high temperature region, the active centers are most likely from Ni–Fe alloy centers. The H2 evolution due to metallic Ni centers is probably merged with in the high temperature H2 evolution peak. The amount of H2 evolved during TPSR with H2O is determined to be ca. 1.34, 1.19, 1.14 and 0.91mmol/g for Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al and Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts, respectively. The H2 evolved during TPSR with H2O and SRT rates (measured from SRT values as in Table 1) with nominal CaO molar content was depicted in Fig. S1. According to Eqs. (5) and (6) this amount of H2 evolved should depend on the amount of reduced species present in the catalysts that correlates with the H2 uptake values presented in Table 3. By comparing the H2 uptakes presented in Table 3 with H2 evolved during TPSR reaction it was observed that all the catalysts generally produced lower amounts of H2 values than the uptake values presented in Table 3. The trend of amount of H2 evolved is similar with the H2 uptakes as in Table 3, except for Ni/Fe(0.5)–Ca–Al catalyst. Finally, the TPSR of water analysis suggests that the superior catalytic performance of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al at relatively low S/C ratio of 2 is possibly because of its ability to activate water molecules at lower temperature than other Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. On the other hand, the lower catalytic performance of Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al over Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts show that even though both can be able to activate the water molecule at similar temperatures, the performance could be explained by the amount of H2 evolved during TPSR with water analysis, whereby the amount of H2 evolved over Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalyst is ca 0.91mmol/g, which is lower than the amount of 1.14mmol/g of H2 evolved over Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst during TPSR with water analysis. 3.2.6 CO-pulse chemisorption The amount of active metal content in the freshly reduced Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts was measured using CO pulse titration at 0°C [59]. The CO uptake values and Ni particles size calculated from CO uptake values were presented in Table 3. It is observed from Table 3 that the CO uptake values decreased with increasing CaO content in the catalyst. This is because with the addition of CaO species to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst, migration of Fe species from bulk to surface of the catalysts was increased (Fe/Ni molar ratios will be shown in Table 4 ). This migrated Fe species can partially encapsulate the surface Ni species. It is noteworthy to mention here that the surface Fe/Ni molar ratios in Table 4 were increased with the addition of CaO species to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. However, the surface contents of Fe and Ni species were decreased and this is can be attributed to the dilution effect of CaO addition to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. Generally, CO uptake values are largely contributed by the available surface metallic Ni species. The affinity towards adsorption of CO over Fe species is much lower than over metallic Ni species. However, on a brighter note, this partial encapsulation can favors the SRT reaction by creating intimate interaction between Ni and Fe species to form Ni–Fe alloy species. Since nickel is the main active component in the present SRT reaction, and intrinsic rate per metal site (turnover frequency, TOF) for the Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts during the SRT reaction was evaluated by considering the toluene conversions shown in Table 1 as well as the CO uptake results presented in Table 3. The TOF values of the Ni supported Fe–Al, Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al, Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al, Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al and Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts are 1.42, 3.40, 4.44, 6.85 and 4.31s−1, respectively. From these TOF values, it is clearly observed that the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst has a higher TOF over the other catalysts and all CaO-doped catalysts have higher TOF values than Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. On the other hand, dispersion values of 0.93, 0.83, 0.76, 0.70 and 0.53% were obtained for the Ni/Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al and Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts, respectively. Thus, these results affirms that the high TOF value of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al attribute for its superior catalytic performance over other catalysts even though it does not have the highest number of available active metallic Ni species among all catalysts. 3.2.7 XPS analysis of reduced and spent catalysts A comparative XPS study was done in order to understand the surface species present in the freshly reduced Ni/Fe–Al, Ni/Ca–Fe–Al and spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts. Fig. 8(a) displays the binding energies (BEs) of Ni 2p3/2 species present in reduced Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. There are two kinds of Ni 2p BEs, firstly due to the presence of Ni0 (∼852.2eV) species and secondly due to the presence of Ni2+ (∼855eV) species, where the Ni2+ species interacts with Fe species present in the Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts [60]. In Fig. 8(a), moving from the profile of Ni/Fe–Al to that of Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al, both BE values of Ni 2p shifted slightly to higher values. This indicates that the Ni species present in Ni/Fe–Al catalyst have weaker interactions with Fe and Al species as compared with those in the CaO-doped Ni/Fe–Al catalysts, affirming the observations in the TPR profiles presented in Fig. 5. Next, the Ni 2p BEs of spent (for 4h reaction time) together with reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst are displayed in Fig. 8(b). It is evident that there exists two kinds of Ni species, namely, Ni0 (BE at 852.8eV) and Ni2+ (BE at 855.5eV) in the spent catalyst. However, the Ni 2p BEs of spent catalyst was shifted slightly to higher values compared with the Ni 2p BE values observed in reduced catalyst. This shift to higher BE values in spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst indicates that the interactions between Ni species and support species (mainly Fe species) were significantly enhanced during the reforming reaction. This hypothesis was further supported by the XRD patterns of spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts (Fig. 4(b)). Fig. 9 displays BEs of Fe 2p3/2 species present in reduced Ni/Fe–Al, Ni/Ca–Fe–Al and spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts. Unlike Ni species, Fe species in Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts can exist in multiple oxidation states and thus, it can be a challenge to identify the exact oxidation states of Fe species present in Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. The following interpretation of the BEs of Fe 2p in Fig. 9 was derived after consideration of numerous literature reports. The Fe 2p BEs of reduced Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts are depicted in Fig. 9(a) which shows that the Fe 2p BE values of 707±0.4 and 711±0.4eV are attributed to presence of Fe0 species and Fe species in Fe3O4 form, respectively. However, according to literature [60], the latter Fe 2p BEs might also attributed to the Fe species that have interacted with Ni species in the catalysts. Next, Fe 2p BEs of reduced and spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst are displayed in Fig. 9(b). The BE values in spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst at around 710.2eV correspond to Fe species in FeO form, while BE values at 712.1eV can be attributed to Fe species present in Fe3O4 form as well as Fe species that are interacted with Ni species. It is also evident that this BE value is shifted to a slightly higher value in the spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst compared with the reduced catalyst. On comparison with Fe 2p BE values present in reduced catalyst, the absence of Fe 2p BE values around 707eV for spent catalyst, corresponding to Fe0 species, suggests the display of redox behavior. During the SRT process, the Fe0 species present in reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst is partially oxidized to form intermediary FeO species. This result indicates that the iron distribution in the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst after SRT reaction is an intermediary phase between the phases FeO and Fe3O4, and is responsible for toluene reforming. These iron species participate in the redox equations of the WGS reaction (Eqs. (7) and (8)): (7) Fe3O4 +CO→2CO2 +3FeO (8) 3FeO+H2O→2H2 +Fe3O4 In the present reaction conditions, the couple Fe2+/3+/Fe2+ species are sufficiently efficient in toluene reforming. This redox behavior enables Fe species to easily shuffle between their oxidation states to enhance the reforming process by enhancing WGS reaction. On the other hand, several researches based on tars cracking from pyrolysis, from biomass gasification [61,62] or based on tar models molecules steam reforming [63–65], in the presence of iron catalysts, have different views on the most dominant active iron oxidation state: FeO, Fe2+ or Fe2+/3+. The molar composition of various surface species present in freshly reduced Ni/Fe–Al, Ni/Ca–Fe–Al and spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalysts are presented in Table 4. According to the Fe/Ni molar ratios presented in Table 4, it can be suggested that the Ni species present in reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst has the highest available Fe species compared to the other catalyst. This also suggests that the addition of CaO to an optimum molar ratio of 1.5 to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst can enhance the available surface Fe species to Ni species. On the other hand, the Fe/Ni molar ratio of ca. 1.07 for spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst suggests that during the course of the SRT reaction, the catalyst Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al was enriched with Fe species. Furthermore, it can be observed that there was a significant decrease in the surface Ca and Al species on the spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst as compared with the reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. In addition, the surface O species were increased in association with Fe species in the spent catalyst compared to reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst, suggesting that this increase in surface oxygen species is possibly due to partial oxidation of Fe species to form FeO species in the steam environment during the SRT reaction. It is well-known that metallic Ni catalysts are widely explored for steam reforming of hydrocarbons because metallic Ni has a strong ability to activate CH and CC bonds in the hydrocarbon molecules on the Ni metal surface [66]. According to Table 4, the amount of surface metallic Ni species is lower in the spent Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst than in the reduced catalyst. This decrease in metallic Ni species is possibly due to the increase in surface Fe species that can partially encapsulate metallic Ni species during SRT process with time on stream [24]. Additionally, the deposition of carbon can also be responsible for the decrease of metallic Ni species during the SRT process, suggesting that the deactivation behavior of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalyst (in Fig. 1) with time on stream is primarily due to the decrease in the amount of metallic Ni species. Finally, the better catalytic performance of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst over other catalysts is attributed to the presence of strong interactions between Ni and Fe species to form Ni–Fe alloy particles that are rich in surface Fe species. The promotional effect of CaO is to enhance the available Fe species to active Ni species in Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts. The phases of these Fe species lie between the phases FeO and Fe3O4 and are highly redox-active in nature providing necessary oxygen species to nearby metallic Ni species to perform better SRT reaction. 3.2.8 DT/TG analyses of spent catalysts The nature and amount of carbon deposited over spent Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts after SRT at 650°C for 4h are measured using TGA/DTA analyses up to 800°C in air. The reaction times of spent catalysts were shown in Fig. 1. The thus-obtained TGA and DTA profiles are presented in Figs. 10 and 11 , respectively. The TGA profiles for all spent catalysts in Fig. 10 shows a slight weight gain between 300 and 450°C and a single stage weight loss between 450 and 700°C. The slight weight gain is due to oxidation of Ni and Fe species present in the spent catalysts and the weight loss is due to the oxidation of deposited carbon species on spent catalysts during SRT reaction [67]. From Fig. 10, the amount of carbon deposited on all the spent catalysts was determined and summarized in Table 5 . It indicates that Ni/Ca–Fe–Al(1.5) catalyst possesses lower amount of carbon formation rate (ca. 14.5mgC/g-cath) as compared to the carbon formation rate of Ni/Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al, Ni/Ca(1.0)–Fe–Al, and Ni/Ca(2.0)–Fe–Al catalysts (ca. 30.4, 26.1, 19 and 17.8mgC/g-cath, respectively). It is also observed that all CaO-doped catalysts generally had lower carbon formation rates as compared to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst. Furthermore, Fig. 11 presents the corresponding DTA profiles as rate of weight loss against temperature. The positivity of all profiles (in Fig. 11) indicates that the weight loss is exothermic in nature due to the oxidation of deposited carbon species [67,68]. The asymmetric nature of these exothermic peaks suggests the presence of several different carbonaceous species. The DTA profile of all catalysts has single exothermic peak. However, the T max for all profiles differs from each other. Fig. 11 also shows that the T max for Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca(0.5)–Fe–Al catalysts are centered at around 650°C and majority of the carbon species were oxidized above 650°C, which is the reaction temperature in this study. In contrast, all other higher CaO-doped catalysts have a T max centered at around 620°C and most of the carbon species were oxidized below 650°C. As reported in the literature, the basic nature of CaO species in the catalysts can increase the steam-carbon reaction by activating steam molecule at lower temperature (in Fig. 7) and they can also neutralize the acidity of the support to suppress cracking and polymerization reactions. By combining these DT/TG results with the surface Fe/Ni molar compositions of reduced Ni/Ca–Fe–Al catalysts presented in Table 4, it can be inferred that the addition of CaO to Ni/Fe–Al catalysts can increase the available surface Fe species to Ni species. These Fe species generally have higher affinity towards oxygen species than Ni species, and this attribute can be helpful in providing oxygen species to Ni species to reform the deposited carbon during SRT reaction. This explains the lower carbon formation rates obtained for higher CaO-doped catalysts than Ni/Fe–Al and Ni/Ca–Fe–Al (0.5) catalysts. Therefore, the deposition of lower amounts carbon and presence of low temperature exothermic peak (ca. 620°C) are attributes for the superior and stable catalytic performance of Ni/Ca–Fe–Al(1.5) catalysts over other catalysts. 4 Conclusions The CaO-doped nickel–iron alloy supported over iron–alumina catalysts were explored for steam reforming of biomass tar model compound at a relatively low steam-to-carbon ratio of 2. The Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst shows the best steam reforming performance in terms of higher catalytic activity and stability for 22h of reaction time. The superior catalytic performance of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al is mainly due to the presence of lower Ni crystallite size, availability of higher amount of surface Fe species to active Ni species (Fe-rich Ni–Fe alloy particles), stronger metal support interaction, and lower carbon deposition rate. The ability of Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst to activate water molecules at lower temperatures over other CaO-doped catalysts also plays a vital role in promoting reforming activity at lower S/C condition. The synergy between Ni and Fe atoms is achieved by forming Fe rich Ni–Fe alloy particles and these particles which are stable even after 22h reaction time are crucial for the high activity of the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst. Finally, these CaO doped Ni/Fe–Al catalysts have great potential for application in the steam reforming of biomass tar at low steam-to-carbon conditions. coredata.dc:description: CaO doped iron–alumina-supported nickel–iron alloy catalysts were tested in a fixed-bed reactor for steam reforming of toluene as a biomass tar model compound at a relatively low steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of 2. The influence of doping CaO to iron–alumina support was also explored for the steam reforming reaction. Ni supported on a CaO(1.5)–Fe2O3–Al2O3 support (Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al) gave superior catalytic performance in terms of activity and stability over other catalysts. Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al gave a toluene conversion of more than 80% for a period of 22h testing at a S/C ratio of 2. XRD analysis showed that the Ni–Fe alloys formed were stable throughout the reforming reaction. It was observed from XPS results that the surface of the reduced Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst was enriched with Fe species compared to other catalysts. These enriched surface Fe species play the role of co-catalysts by increasing the coverage of oxygen species during the reforming reaction to enhance the reaction of toluene and to suppress coke formation. The temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with water reveals that the Ni/Ca(1.5)–Fe–Al catalyst can activate water molecule at relatively lower temperature over other CaO doped catalysts. TGA analysis on spent catalysts reveals that all CaO-containing catalysts generally result in lower carbon formation rates as compared to Ni/Fe–Al catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Steam reforming of biomass tar model compound at relatively low steam-to-carbon condition over CaO-doped nickel–iron alloy supported over iron–alumina catalysts
